rComments: She can sometimes come off as condescending. Often times her long-winded explanations confused students and during the break one student would retell the points more concisely. It was a course that was supposed to introduce non-linguistic majors to linguistics but I personally felt it would be hard for them. However she graded easily.

Homework assignments are very unclear. Her assignments dont specify what is wanted and how much info is needed to answer a question, marking scheme is odd, losing 3 points for missing out 1 detail of info.  In Lecture, she goes on a lot tangents .  I leave the lecture confused but tutorials are very helpful and clarify a lot.

Homework is 30% of the grade yet is a disorganized mess; unacceptable for a significant component. They're equally long and inscrutable: there is no indication of what questions are worth or what is expected in an answer; questions are often so poorly phrased that you can't tell what's being asked. TAs marking are instructed not to write feedback.
She goes on tangents. Examples are often overly complicated. Grading criteria is not clear. Not the worst teacher ever, but I would recommend taking the class with another lecturer if possible.

Although her lack of experience sometimes shows (we had to change classrooms due to a scheduling error), she's nevertheless a competent teacher. My only complaint is that she tries too hard to remove the "formality" of semantics to make it seem less "mathematical"- sometimes leading to confusion. But this' a flaw with the course, not her.

This lecturer is so confusing. She seems like she doesn't know the material. Not a professor i would recommend. She is often dismissive when asked a question saying ' we wont talk about that now'.   She reads off of the slides and does not allow recording of lectures.

Ippolito is very confusing lecturer. The textbook she uses contradicts her lectures and is useless. When asked to clarify she often was dismissive and unhelpful. Her assignments were difficult and covered material that she had yet to talk about in class. I would not recommend this course.
